body:
Before we begin this Learning Moment, let's reflect on your experiences of giving feedback.


As a leader, how confident do you feel about giving feedback to your team?
title: New Article Title

body:
In our dynamic and fast-paced retail environment, work is changing faster than ever before.


To remain agile, adapt to new ways of working, and to continuously improve, we need to keep learning and growing.


Leaders at Myer can help others learn and grow by providing constructive feedback.


Constructive feedback is a two-way conversation that involves both giving and responding to feedback. 


This Learning Moment will focus on how you can give the best feedback to others every day.
title: Screen - 5

displayTitle: “Mistakes should be examined, learned from, and discarded; not dwelled upon and stored.”
title: Screen - 6

body: To give constructive feedback, consider the type of feedback you want to provide based on the situation. Press below to find out more about each type.
title: Screen - 7

displayTitle: ​THE BENEFITS OF EACH TYPE OF FEEDBACK​
body:
Each type of feedback has different characteristics and benefits. 


Press on the question marks below to learn more about each feedback style:
title: Screen - 8

displayTitle: “Success is not final, failure is not fatal: It’s the courage to continue that counts.”
title: Screen - 11

body:
It helps to have a plan for how you want to deliver feedback. This enables you to enter a conversation feeling prepared and confident you will do a good job.


By following three simple steps, feedback can be an easy process for you and your team.

Remember to find a private space where you won’t be interrupted.

Press each of the three steps below to learn more.
title: Screen - 5_2

body:
Read the corrective feedback conversation between store leaders below and move each part of the conversation into the correct order. Remember, the conversation should begin by identifying the actions, followed by the impact this has on others, and finally the desired outcome.


Read the quotes below and sort them into the correct sequence.
title: GF_Sorting_1_title

body:
Read the reinforcing feedback conversation between store leaders below and move each part of the conversation into the correct order.


Read the quotes below and sort them into the correct sequence.
title: GF_Sorting_2_title

body:
People can have different reactions to feedback. From delight to surprise and more negative emotions. Being ready to deal with different reactions is key to giving the best feedback.

Press below for tips to manage different reactions.
title: Screen - 9

body: Robert Allen
title: Screen - 9

body:
Take a moment to reflect on how you could give better feedback by considering the following questions.


How can you be more aware of your impact when giving feedback?


How can you give feedback as part of your everyday conversations?


How can you ask more questions when giving feedback?
title: Screen - 10

body:
Spend a second noting down any actions you will take to give more constructive feedback.


As a starting point, you could consider having at least one feedback conversation with each team member per week.
title: Screen - 5

body:
You’ve nearly reached the end of the giving feedback Learning Moment.


Do you remember how you rated your confidence at the beginning? 


Having learnt more about giving feedback, how confident do you feel about giving feedback to your team?
title: Screen - 5
